verses.text: O God, why have You rejected us forever? Why does Your anger burn against the sheep of Your pasture?
verses.comment: The psalmist begins with a lament, asking why God’s apparent rejection is lasting. The phrase 'sheep of Your pasture' recalls Israel as God's chosen people and the theme of God as shepherd. See also John 10:11, where Jesus calls Himself the Good Shepherd.

verses.text: Remember Your people, whom You purchased long ago, the tribe of Your inheritance, whom You redeemed—Mount Zion, where You dwell.
verses.comment: References to redemption and inheritance point both to the Exodus and to aspects of New Testament redemption (Eph. 1:7). The mention of Zion is a sign of God’s dwelling among His people, a theme fulfilled in the incarnate Christ (John 1:14).

verses.text: Turn Your steps toward these everlasting ruins, all the destruction the enemy has inflicted in the sanctuary.
verses.comment: The 'sanctuary' refers to the Temple, the place of God’s special presence. The destruction alludes to the Babylonian invasion. The concern for the sanctuary underscores the tangible means by which God’s grace comes to His people—a concept continued in sacramental theology.

verses.text: Your foes roared in the place of Your assemblies; they set up their banners as signs.
verses.comment: Foreign enemies desecrating the place of worship prefigures later attacks against the Church but also God's promise to preserve His true worship across ages.

verses.text: They were like men who swing axes among the thicket of trees.
verses.comment: An image of invaders hacking and destroying, emphasizing the violence done to what is holy. The axe in Scripture is sometimes a symbol of impending judgment (Matt. 3:10).

verses.text: With axes and hatchets, they smashed all its carved work.
verses.comment: Carved work refers to the ornamentation of the Temple, demonstrating the loss of beauty and dignity meant for God’s house. This highlights reverence owed to places set apart for divine worship.

verses.text: They set Your sanctuary on fire; they profaned the dwelling place of Your Name, bringing it down to the ground.
verses.comment: Fire in judgment often reflects the seriousness of sacrilege. The 'dwelling place of Your Name' echoes themes of God’s real presence in designated spaces (Ex. 40:34-38).

verses.text: They said in their hearts, 'Let us crush them completely.' They burned down all the meeting places of God in the land.
verses.comment: The deliberate destruction shows an intent to erase God’s worship from among the people, a pattern seen repeatedly in salvation history and resisted by God’s faithful remnant.

verses.text: We do not see our signs; no prophet is left, and none of us knows how long this will last.
verses.comment: Prophets were mediators of God's will in times of crisis. The absence of prophecy underlines the depth of spiritual desolation. Christians later see Christ as the fulfillment of prophet, priest, and king (Acts 3:22-23).

verses.text: How long, O God, will the adversary scorn? Will the enemy blaspheme Your Name forever?
verses.comment: A plea for God's vindication and the end of suffering, typical in lament psalms. The language anticipates prayers for the coming of the Messiah and for the final victory over evil (Rev. 6:10).

verses.text: Why do You hold back Your hand, Your right hand? Take it from Your robe, and destroy them!
verses.comment: God's 'right hand' is a symbol of power and intervention. The request for action shows faith in God’s historical interventions, paralleling Christ seated at the right hand of the Father (Heb. 1:3).

verses.text: Yet God is my King from of old, working salvation in the midst of the earth.
verses.comment: A profession of faith: despite suffering, God remains King and brings salvation, not just spiritually but in history and sacramentally.

verses.text: You divided the sea by Your strength; You broke the heads of the sea monsters in the waters.
verses.comment: Refers to the Exodus and the defeat of chaos creatures. In Christian theology, the parting of the sea prefigures baptism, a passage from death to life (1 Cor. 10:1-2).

verses.text: You crushed the heads of Leviathan; You gave him as food for the creatures of the desert.
verses.comment: Leviathan symbolizes chaos and evil. God’s defeat of the serpent is a theme that culminates in Christ’s victory over Satan (Rev. 12:9).

verses.text: You opened up springs and streams; You dried up ever-flowing rivers.
verses.comment: Miraculous provision, as at Meribah, but also a demonstration God is Lord over nature. These works prefigure spiritual realities in the sacraments.

verses.text: The day is Yours, and Yours also the night; You established the light and the sun.
verses.comment: Affirms God as Creator, sovereign over all creation, a key affirmation of the faith (see the Creed).

verses.text: You set all the boundaries of the earth; You made summer and winter.
verses.comment: The cycles of nature reveal God’s order and providence. Seasonal rhythms are signs of God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: Remember this, O LORD: how the enemy scoffed and how a foolish people blasphemed Your Name.
verses.comment: The psalmist appeals to God’s honor. In the New Testament, Christ teaches us to forgive enemies yet to defend the sacred with perseverance.

verses.text: Do not hand over the life of Your dove to wild beasts; do not forget the lives of Your afflicted people forever.
verses.comment: The dove often symbolizes purity and the Spirit (cf. Matt. 3:16). God’s people are precious to Him.

verses.text: Remember Your covenant, for the dark places of the earth are full of violence.
verses.comment: God’s covenant is central; even amid darkness, the promise endures. Christians see the New Covenant as the true fulfillment of God’s promise (Luke 22:20).

verses.text: Do not let the oppressed turn away in shame; let the poor and needy praise Your Name.
verses.comment: The poor and humble have a privileged place in God’s plan of salvation (cf. Luke 4:18; James 2:5).

verses.text: Arise, O God, defend Your cause; remember how fools mock You all day long!
verses.comment: The psalmist appeals for God’s public defense of His Name. Anticipates Christ’s passion, where He entrusted vindication to the Father (1 Pet. 2:23).

verses.text: Do not forget the clamor of Your foes, the uproar of those who rise against You, which goes up continually.
verses.comment: The psalm closes with a call to God to remember the persistent opposition of the wicked. The final vindication is fulfilled in Christ’s triumph (Rev. 19:11-16).
